qas.question: Why do almost all carriers using conventional aircraft have arrested-recovery systems?

answers.text: conventional aircraft cannot decelerate on their own

qas.question: What is the purpose of an arrested-recovery system?
What do aircraft do when landing in order to stop on a short distance?

answers.text: extend a tailhook that catches on arrestor wires stretched across the deck

qas.question: What does a landing area angles off access allow an aircraft to do if if misses the arresting wires?
What can a "bolt" prevent an aircraft from doing?

answers.text: crashing into aircraft on the forward deck

qas.question: Why do almost all carriers using nonconventional aircraft have arrested-recovery systems?
What is not the purpose of an arrested-recovery system?

plausible_answers.text: extend a tailhook that catches on arrestor wires stretched across the deck

qas.question: What do aircraft do when landing in order to stop on a long distance?
What does a landing area angles off access allow an aircraft to do if it catches the arresting wires?

plausible_answers.text: crashing into aircraft on the forward deck

qas.question: What can a "bolt" allow an aircraft to do?

context: On the recovery side of the flight deck, the adaptation to the aircraft loadout is mirrored. Non-VTOL or <a0_0>conventional aircraft <b5_0>cannot decelerate on their own<b5_0/><a0_0/>, and almost all carriers using them must have arrested-recovery systems (-BAR, e.g. CATOBAR or STOBAR) <a1_0>to <b6_0>recover their aircraft<b6_0/><a1_0/>. Aircraft that are landing <a2_0><b7_0>extend a tailhook that catches on arrestor wires stretched across the deck<b7_0/><a2_0/> to bring themselves to a stop in a short distance. Post-WWII Royal Navy research on safer CATOBAR recovery eventually led to universal adoption of a landing area angled off axis to allow aircraft who missed the arresting wires to "<a3_0><b8_0>bolt<b8_0/><a3_0/>" and safely return to flight for another landing attempt rather than <a4_0><b9_0>crashing into aircraft on the forward deck<b9_0/><a4_0/>.
